sub_topic: Calculation of magnetic field due to a current-carrying motor
message_1: A current-carrying motor has a wire of length 20 cm carrying a current of 5 A. Determine the magnitude of the magnetic field at a point 10 cm away from the wire.
message_2:
To determine the magnitude of the magnetic field at a point 10 cm away from the wire, we can use the formula for the magnetic field due to a straight current-carrying wire, which is given by:

B = (μ₀ * I) / (2 * π * r)

where B is the magnetic field, μ₀ is the permeability of free space (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A), I is the current in the wire, and r is the distance from the wire.

In this case, I = 5 A and r = 10 cm = 0.1 m. Plugging these values into the formula, we get:

B = (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A * 5 A) / (2 * π * 0.1 m)

The π in the numerator and denominator cancels out:

B = (4 × 10^(-7) Tm * 5 A) / (2 * 0.1 m)

Now, we can simplify the expression:

B = (20 × 10^(-7) T) / 0.2 m

B = (2 × 10^(-6) T) / 0.02 m

B = 10^(-4) T

So, the magnitude of the magnetic field at a point 10 cm away from the wire is 10^(-4) T or 100 μT.
